comments.text:
+sada asdafa The ruling didn't come in until a much later date in fact well 
over a century later. Not really anything to do with the Tudors.It was all 
about the fights within the House of Stuart. The ruling came in because 
James VII of Scotland and II of England converted to Catholicism then had a 
baby, James Stuart, the future Old Pretender. The baby had two older 
Protestant sisters, Mary and Anne, but because he was male he was heir to 
the throne so both Scotland and England looked like having a Catholic royal 
dynasty restored. Mary and her husband (William of Orange) were invited by 
some in England to restore the Protestant throne so William invaded England 
and James fled. Once he lost his English power base the Scottish parliament 
branded James a traitor and offered the Scottish throne to William and Mary 
too. They later died without heirs so the younger sister Anne Stuart took 
the throne but she had no heir either so the most obvious next monarch was 
her nephew the exiled James Stuart the Old Pretender. The Scottish 
parliament had passed a law saying that the Scottish monarch needed to be 
both of the Scottish Royal Line and Protestant which paved a way for James 
to return were he to convert from Catholicism. The English Parliament 
looked to exclude James altogether so they passed the law which not only 
excluded Catholics but specifically stated that the future English monarch 
would be Sophie of Hanover and her descendents. Sophie was the daughter of 
Princess Elizabeth of Scotland the elder sister of Charles I. While Anne 
was still alive the union between Scotland and England happened and the 
Hanovarian Succession was one of the articles of the said union treaty 
which created the new united kingdom called Great Britain. In fact that is 
one of the major reasons union came about. The English parliament wanted to 
ensure Scotland chose the same monarch as England. Sophie was already dead 
prior to Anne dying herself so Sophie's son George I became monarch on 
Anne's death.
comments.author: allan connochie

comments.text:
the Act of Sucession (the Act Grey is talking about) specifically removes 
anyone NOT Protestant AND a descendant of Sophie of Hanover- keeping the 
Catholic Church away and within a select line of people.

Previously, post Henry VIII the crown of England passed to Catholic or 
Catholic friendly rulers, some of  whom instigated some really terrible 
crimes against England- the Stuarts waging expensive wars against supposed 
allies, Mary Tudor having killed more people than any monarch in witchhunts 
against Protestants (usually by burning), the Jacobite Rebellion as well as 
the Catholic-supported installation of Mary Queen of Scots up north. Not to 
mention Catholic plots against Elizabeth I , real and imagined. Oliver 
Cromwell's rebellion that unseated Charles I was based partly on a fear of 
control of the country through the Pope.

To tie up sucession in the hands of a single, Protestant dynasty Parliament 
passed the Act, which brought in George I and the beginning of the rule of 
the Hanoverians, who were very un-Catholic.

The attitude even carried on to colonies like the Americas, where parties 
like the Know Nothings and groups lsimilarly the Ku Klux Klan formed partly 
to discriminate against Irish and German immigrants, who they felt would 
give the Pope control over the USA.  The state of Georgia itself was 
initially founded on a motto of "no alcohol, no slaves and no Papists".
comments.author: SantomPh

comments.text:
In the end, it boils down to one thing: The Pope. The rule against 
Catholicism was mostly designed (apart from the Head of Anglicanism thing) 
to prevent the Pope having any influence in the Kingdom. This is largely a 
result of the Tudor era when the pope was able to exert his influence on 
whole Kingdoms by various means, including the threat of excommunication 
(which Henry VIII took exception to, admittedly for selfish reasons). This 
is also the reason why, until VERY recently, the monarch was not allowed 
even to marry a Catholic.

comments.text:
+Jordan Lawe
That should be easy.  

1. Democracy.  
Having a monarch is antiquated tradition and the head of state should be an 
elected not a hereditary position.  

2. Revenue.  
The British Monarchy pays no inheritance tax.  The British Tax payer has to 
make up the difference.  The Royal activities also cost the British 
Taxpayer many millions of pounds.  They also stifle tourism revenue because 
they occupy the historic palace that limits the number of days people can 
come to visit.  Paris's historic sites get far more visitors.  

3. Separation of church and state.  
Britain's official state religion is Anglicanism despite the vast number of 
non believers that live there.  The Monarchy's claim to the throne rests on 
the assertion that God put them there according to tradition and royal 
documents.  We all know that isn't true and we should stop pretending for 
the sake of tradition.

It's worth noting that, while you can't be a Catholic, you can be literally 
anything else, as not being a protestant or a Catholic in England wasn't 
really a thing when they made these rules. So if William converts to Islam 
or Scientology or neo-paganism, according to the rules that won't stop him 
being head of the Church of England.

Also, you can't just be a descendant of William the Bastard Conquerer, so 
sadly I'm not in line, and you probably aren't either. You have to be 
descended from Sofia of Hannover, who was around in 1701 when they made the 
rules. The long list of succession is interesting, as pretty much every 
European royal is on there. So Prince Phillip could be king, but he doesn't 
just need to outlive his wife, he needs to outlive about eighty other 
people.﻿

comments.text:
Hanging, drawing, and quartering
This was the punishment in England for treason. The man was drawn on a 
hurdle pulled by a horse to the place of execution. He was hanged 
(strangled by being suspended by a rope) but when he was still alive and 
sometimes conscious he was cut down. The executioner cut open his stomach 
and 'drew out' his entrails. Finally the man was beheaded and his body was 
cut into quarters.

Unfortunately this no longer is in place, so you would probably just go to 
jail for life or get the electric chair.

+Th3Muzza Hey, I'm not anti-monarchy, indeed I like the monarchy and the 
way the government is set up now.  However, I think that Britain will never 
become a republic for at least our lifetimes.  We need the Queen to be able 
to grant or deny royal assent to bills if a situation should arise such as 
a tyranny formed by parliament.  We need someone who can check their 
power.  Public servants swear allegiance to the Queen because she is the 
personification of the State, indeed she is the Head of State.  This is 
true in courtrooms, where if you sue the government then it would be:  R v. 
Th3Muzza, "R" standing for Regina (Latin for Queen) or Rex (for King).  
However, it's read as, The Crown against Th3Muzza, or in Australia, The 
Queen against Th3Muzza.
comments.author: Henry Whitmore

comments.author: Th3Muzza

comments.text:
+Henry Whitmore There, you have just summed up the inherent issues with 
Monarchy. MPs and public servants shouldn't have to swear allegiance to the 
Queen, yet I believe Republican MPs still do.

It is, very undemocratically and archaically, technically illegal to 
advocate a Republic. However, (2003, I think it was) the High Court ruled 
that advocating a Republic is not treason, so long as it is done peacefully.

As to a bill for a Republic requiring Royal Assent: I see where you are 
coming from, in that every bill requires it to be passed in to law. 
However, if a majority of British people were in support of a Republic, 
then that also means that a majority of British people don't accept that 
bills need to be accepted by the Queen, therefore the people would proceed 
whether the bill was given Royal Assent or not.

comments.text:
I think that is a more complicated question than it appears. The Act of 
Settlement as passed by the English parliament and accepted by the Scots as 
part of the union settlement specifically excludes Catholics. Though of 
course it was drawn up to exclude one specific branch of the royal family. 
There was no possibility at that time that a non-Christian would be monarch 
so legislation would be deemed irrelevent. This Act and union settlement 
though did not necessarily override the existing Scottish settlement (as 
stated in the Claim of Right) that the monarch should be of the true 
Protestant religion (ie Presbyterian) and of the Scottish royal line. The 
current monarch is still of the Scottish royal line and as soon as she 
crosses the border she symbolically stops being Head of the Church of 
England and becomes a member of the Presbyterian Church of Scotland.

In truth who would be accepted as monarch would in the end be up to the 
opinion of the public. British constitution is based on precedent and is 
flexible so can be changed. There was no law stating that a monarch 
couldn't marry an American divorcee yet a reigning king was forced to 
abdicate when he chose to do so because of opinion and attitudes at that 
time. I'd imagine the British public would have much less opposition to 
accepting a Catholic than they would a Moslem (for example) one.
comments.author: allan connochie

comments.text:
+KingsofSparta It's really simple, and you may be over thinking it. Here's 
what Grey said:
-Before 2013, if a monarch was expecting twins of opposite sexes, the boy 
would get the crown regardless of whether or not he was born first.
-From 2013 onward, if a monarch was expecting twins of opposite sexes, 
whichever twin is born first gets the crown regardless of gender. If the 
girl is born first, she will be queen. If the boy is born first, he will be 
king. Gender no longer matters.

comments.text:
Just going to throw my relatively informed tuppence worth into this 
discussion. The current Act of Succession 1701 (the 2013 amendment is not 
yet law until all 15 commonwealth nations have also passed the equivalent 
law) defines those in line of succession to be only the lineal descendants 
of George I's mother, the Electress Sophia of Hannover. Said descendants 
currently number something like 5000 legitimate living individuals (though 
many are or may be Catholics), so you would 'only' need to 'forcibly 
remove' a few thousand people from the succession to completely wipe the 
whole line out and force parliament to pass a new succession law that 
starts with a new individual, and said new individual is almost certain to 
be an ancestor in the line that led to Sophia in the first place, or else a 
later descendant of such an ancestor. Since Sophia's line is the last 
genealogical line from James VI&I (many others having been stepped over by 
the 1701 act due to Catholicism) then the new individual would probably 
have to be from further up, but James was the only surviving son of Mary, 
Queen of Scots, herself the only surviving child of James V of Scotland, 
himself only surviving child of Margaret Tudor's first marriage to James 
IV, so the next ancestor chosen for a succession law would probably be a 
descendant of Margaret's second marriage to Archibald Douglas, Earl of 
Angus, via her daughter Margaret Douglas, grandson Charles Stuart, Earl of 
Lennox (brother of Lord Darnley who was married to Mary, Queen of Scots), 
and great granddaughter Arabella Stuart who married the Duke of Somerset. 
In the event that there are no remaining descendants in this line (I don't 
know for sure off the top of my head), then the next line parliament would 
probably choose is that of Margaret Tudor's sister, Mary Tudor, which was 
the line followed by supporters of Lady Jane Grey, who was said to have 
reigned for 9 days. There are several thousand descendants of Mary Tudor 
(some having already been dispatched as descendants of Sophia of Hannover 
in the previous round of 'forcible removable') so another round of 
'forcible removable', this time of all Mary Tudor's living descendants, 
would then lead to parliament to have to decide which genealogical line to 
follow next, since all legitimate descendants of Henry VII would now be 
removed. Acting as if Bosworth hadn't happened, and reinstating Richard 
III's succession prior to that battle, would not resolve the issue 
entirely, as it was already unclear who would succeed Richard III, and 
whether or not it was he, or one of Edward IV's remaining descendants, who 
was the actual legitimate claimant of the throne. Nonetheless even if we 
could define the order of succession of the many hundreds of thousands of 
heirs of Edward IV's father, and therefore the entire Yorkist claim, and 
ensure we then 'forcibly removed' them from succession, parliament would 
then, in effect, either have to choose to maintain the Yorkist claim back 
through the line of primogeniture from Edward III, via the Clarence and 
March families, or else to effectively reverse the wars of the roses and 
reinstate the Lancastrian succession (further complicated from there 
actually being two Lancastrian claims, the one we think we know which 
logically starts with Henry IV's usurpation of the throne and is confined 
to his issue, and the one actually made by Henry IV, that he was the 
rightful heir to the throne through his mother, due to his father's line 
being ineligible because of the supposedly invalid marriages made by Edward 
I, which would make Henry IV the rightful heir of Henry III and lead to 
many thousands of additional Lancastrian heirs). Suppose parliament has 
somehow navigated all this confusion, made a publicly accepted decision on 
which line to follow next at every turn, and correctly identified each and 
every valid descendant in each respective line, and that somehow every 
identified person has in some way been subsequently removed from the 
succession, either naturally or forcibly, then by now we have seen maybe 
millions of people in the UK, Europe, US, Canada, Australia and many other 
places 'removed' from the succession, and if we continued to keep going 
back until we exhaust all provable descendants of William the Conqueror 
then that number would surely be tens or even hundreds of millions, but 
crucially there will always be millions upon millions of others who have no 
known and provable descent from an English or UK monarch, and millions more 
who's only known descent(s) come through an indisputably illegitimate link 
(some cases could be overcome if the illegitimacy was debatable, or 
subsequently legitimised (think of the legitimised Beaufort's descent being 
Henry VII's main genealogical claim to the throne) but most cases could 
not, so many millions of people who were relying on simply waiting in line 
would never see the throne, even if hundreds of millions of others in line 
had somehow been 'removed' from the succession first. Even for those 
waiting in line, and planning to 'remove' the people ahead of them in some 
systematic way, it would still prove very difficult to identify and remove 
every single person in the way, whilst at the same time escaping justice at 
every turn, the odds would just be insurmountable. To go back to +Green 
Phoenix 's original point you would have to be a descendant, in a wholly 
legitimate line, of an English/British monarch, or at least be able to 
produce a convincing argument to legitimise the previously illegitimate 
link that was debarring you.

comments.text:
+allan connochie No it's actually you who is getting ahead of yourself. 
Although the new law has been approved and added to the books in the UK, it 
does not actively come into effect until all 15 commonwealth countries have 
passed a law to an identical effect within their own legal systems. The two 
biggest commonwealth countries are the biggest delayers in this respect, 
Australia is actually made up of several states who usually pass their own 
laws, rather than laws being made nationally, and although some states were 
happy to let the law be passed at a national, rather than state, level in 
this specific case, there were some states, Queensland in particular, that 
felt this was against the Australian constitution so tried to hastily pass 
their own law first, which may have ironically had the effect of preventing 
the proposed national law from being able to take legal effect. In Canada 
there is a similar problem, although this time the main problem is with the 
french-speaking province Quebec, who aren't exactly monarchist in the first 
place, but whose laws need to be altered before a Canadian law can be 
passed, in turn before the whole law can take effect in the UK and all the 
other commonwealth countries. The whole process could take at least another 
year, or possibly even several years. It's even feasible that law changes 
could be permanently prevented in one or more commonwealth countries, or 
their constituent parts, which would prevent the law change from ever 
coming into effect. So in summary as it stands the law hasn't changed, and, 
to use the closest immediate example where the different rules would 
actually have an effect, if the Princess Royal's daughter, Zara Tindall, 
were to get immediately pregnant again, and have a son before the agreement 
was made, then he would still be ahead of her newborn daughter Mia, at #13 
to her #14, in the succession, at least until the changes did come into 
effect (the changes themselves being retrospective to an already specified 
date in 2011).

captions.text: How to become the British Monarch:

Historically, the crown sat upon your head
mostly because you had the biggest army. When

you died usually your eldest son kept control
over that army and so the crown relocated

to his head, though, of course, someone with
a bigger army could change the political landscape
quite abruptly.

As time marched on and the world grew less
violent eventually in 1701 Parliament established

a set of rules to transfer the crown from
one head to another -- hopefully with less
turmoil than before.
So here's how the 1701 rules work:
Frist: don't be Catholic.

The British Monarch is also the head of the
Church of England to which the monarch much

convert if not already a member. Except that
if you're Catholic, no crown for you.

The history of the royal family and how this
rule came to be is a story for another time,

but suffice it to say that bigger-army diplomacy
was involved.

And, BTW, no you can't cleverly get around
this rule by converting from Catholicism to

something else then to Church of England.
In the eyes of the crown, Catholicism is transitive.
Second: don't be a bastard.

Sometimes it's good to be the king, but it's
never good to be the illegitimate children

of the king -- who are out of line for the
crown literally from the moment of their conception.

If you're related to the monarch but are either
a Catholic or a bastard or both, the crown

has the delightful term 'Naturally Dead' to
refer to you and your lack of right to succession.
Third spouses don't count.

While people often think of kings and queens
as a pair: that's not the way it works here.

Spouses of Monarchs are known as Royal Consorts.
They may be called 'prince' or 'queen' but

as far as the crown is concerned, they're
not in line for the throne, they're just the

matching 23 Chromosomes needed for the creation
of the real heir.
Fourth and Finally: Male Primogeniture (whatever).

This is the algorithm of inheritance. When
the Monarch dies -- or abdicates -- but usually

dies -- the crown goes to the eldest son who
isn't 'naturally dead'. If there happens to

be an elder daughter tough luck to her: baby
brother gets the crown.

It's Simple enough, but there are non-obvious
cases: take a king with two sons: if the eldest

dies before the king does, obviously the crown
goes to the youngest (now oldest) brother.

But what if the eldest son gave the king a
grandson before death? Where does the crown
go then?

Well, the crown basically pretends that everyone
-- except the naturally dead -- is alive:

so upon the death of the king the crown goes
to his eldest son -- who is now sort of the

king who just really happens to be dead -- so
the rule kicks in again, and the crown goes

to *his* son, not as seems obvious now, his
brother.

But if this 1701 rule means that eldest sons
get the crown, how did queens ever come to

be? Basically, daughters were the last choice
of the crown, which is why there have been
so few.

To get the crown, a daughter had to be either
the only child of the monarch or the eldest
child without competing brothers.

So pregnant mothers must have made any daughters
with queenly aspirations quite nervous.

Now sometimes the branch of a family tree
die out: be it from war or plague or whatever

so the crown's contingency plan if it's at
a dead end is to back up one level, and then

apply the rules forward again looking for
a living head to sit upon. If no luck, back

up again, and repeat and repeat until a living
heir is found.

And there will always be an heir. The first
king of England was over a thousand years

ago and the mathematics of human reproduction
backed up by DNA evidence reveals that just

about every European alive is distantly related
to him. So the crown will eventually find
a way.

So from the first king through the new millennium,
the various rules when along, making monarchs,

though with a gender biased result, that no
one seemed too bothered about until suddenly,

in 2013 for no particular reason at all, everyone
decided that the rules needed to be updated
*right now*.

So, Parliament and the Monarchy got together
and made some changes: most notably striking
the male part of rule #4.

From 2013 on the crown views all royal sons
and daughters with equal favor. The only thing
that matters is the order of their birth.

So prior to 2013 the boy in a set of fraternal
twins in development could sit back and relax

-- secure that the crown would be his no matter
what happened on delivery day, but in the

post 2013 gender-equal world it's now a race
for the door to win the crown.

title: How to Become the British Monarch
